document.text: Wheu sheriff Coleman passed out of the building to the broad stone porch, he was accosted by R. H. Browning, and the heated words that ensued soon led to blows, sev eral of which were exchanged. A very few minutes after the difficulty, Field Smith, a well-known resident of Appomattox, denounced the sher iff, and another difficulty was nar rowly averted. Mr. Coleman has been sheriff of Appomattox county for a good many years. He will be opposed in his candidacy for re-election to the office spring after next by Mr. Frank W. McKinney. A gentleman from Appomattox who arrived in the city yesterday said to a reporter of the News that Mr. Coleman had stated to several parties since the political meeting on Thursday, that he was a candidate for the legislature as the floater from Appbmattox and Campbell. Mr. Coleman has been a staunch Democrat for many years, and his action has been a surprise to his many friends. On Friday Mr Coleman told a friend that he was iu the fight and I mean business. The editor of this paper was not present when the altercation between the sheriff and Mr. Browning took place nor when the sheriff announced himself an independent candidate for the House of Delegates, but from the leliable information we liather there seems to be little doubt that the report given of the affair by the News is correct, except that which is corrected by card is this issue.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. document.text: In 1871 came Richard F. Burke from Burkeville, Nottaway County, Virginia and settled in what is n6w the Town of Appomattox. He w.s local agent for the Virginia and Tennessee Railroad. Later the name was changed to Norfolk and Western and he continued with them for some time. Being a man of much energy, he was active in other business and civic undertak-1 ings. He and Frank W. McKinney, operated a fertilizer business un -1 der the firm name of Burke  Mc Kinney, which was a successful en terprise and rendered a service to the community. Later, seeing the necessity of a medium of exchange for Appomattox County, he went to work, organized and founded The Bank of Appomattox. It prov ed to be a success and a further evidence of his foresight and sound judgment. Around the turn of the century he Was elected treasurer of the county, which oifiea he held for a number of yevs in fact, until his death in 19-14. He was st ir.an of scerling qualt.cs, always pror.vpt and  errct in . 1 of his tra sat tions and hel l the respect and confidence of the people.  After the cour house burned in 1892, quite a few citizens were in favor of moving the court house to the Town of Appomattox.There was considerable opposition to th removal. An election was held and the outcome showed a majority in favor of rebuilding the court house in the Town of Appomattox, In stead of on the old site. This ma- jjrity was secured in spite of the fact that any voter who did not vote was recorded as against re moval. Col. Richard F. Burke took a leading part in the election and made speeches a.l over the county,

At this place the clouds seem ed to separate, but quickly gathered one mile northwest, and so damaged many of the crops that the plow is already turning under the broken stalks and torn leave. Among the snfferers on this side of the county who lose heavily, and who are, prob ably without insurance, are James 1 Caldwell, M. C. Caldwell, Frank W.  McKinney, II. C. Babcock, L. M. Mitchell, Geo. Miles, Jos. Garrett, Jno. Thornhill, Jno. Martin, Edgar  Martin, and numerous other smallei farmers. The storm passed on into Amherst county, where it wrought great havoc to crops and bridges. Our people gather and talk of the destruction. While all business will feel the effects of it, many console themselves by saying that the prices which tobacco is now bringing would hardly have paid the fertilizer bills, any way.  The oldest inhabitants say that it was tbe most disastrous storm which ever visited the county I in their lime.

document.text: Frank W, McKinney, the pop ular Sheriff of Appomattox county, passed away at his old ancestral home, near this town, Sunday evening, in the 61st year of his age. Since January last Mr McKinney had been a great sufferer, and many hospitals and surgeons had been visited in the hope of finding some relief. Early in this month he suffered an op eration in a Lyncaburg hospit al, which operation revealed his troublecancer. After his wound healed he was brought home, where the tenderest care has been administered by his wife aud brother. He contin ued to suffer, and grew weaker each day until the end came, which was a great relief to his suffering frame. Frank was born and reared in the home where he died. He was a faith ful and courageous officer, and possessed the confidence and esteem of the public in the highest degree. He was a member of the Presbyterian church, and was full recon ciled to his God and feUow- man. The deceased is survived by his wife and little daugh ter, Frankie and the follow ing brothers and sisters J. W. and J, L. McKinney, and Mrs. C. A. Poore, of Lynchburg H. Winston McKinney, Appomat tox Mrs. Kate Wright and Mrs. Fannie McKinney, of Roanoke and Mr. William McKinney, of the U, S. army. The funeral took place from his late home and was conduct ed by his pastor, Kev. J. C Le,.s, where a-large crowd of relatives and friends had as sembled, many from Roanoke and Lynchburg, and this coun tyalthough the weather was threatening, a laige crowd of the friends of this popular citi zen came to pay a last respect to a departed friend. Hand some floral designs bedecked his grave. Mrs. Bessie James and Mrs. ft. E. Caldwell, jr., sang very sweetly several selections. The following acted as pall bearers Dr. D. N. Twyman, Messrs W. B. Gala well, Robert Irby, B. G. Anderson, J. O. Woodson and ..A. il. Clement,

document.text: Hop  and Supper at H otel A ppom attox. On the evening of July 27th there occurred an event which, for the en joyment of the moment and for the pleasant memories engendered,stands conspicuously eminent in the social annals of Appomattox. It was a hop given by the yonng men of our town. Concdrd, Spout Spring, Campbell, Prince Edward and Appo mattox furnished delegations of the most beautiful, and toilets of ex quisite and artistic taste. There was a lovely night with the fu ll moon shedding its mellow light, there were the sweet strains of music with the rythmic shuffling of dancing feet, and there was the merry talk and laughter of the gay participants, all combining to render the occasion pe culiarly enjoyable and a pronounced success. The future can contain nothing pleasanter than a repetition, and Appomattox may well say that for her to undertake is to succeed. The young ladies present and their toilets were as follows. Miss M. document.text: Thursday at noon at Libe tv Baptist Church here the marriage of Miss Lillie Neal Hancock to Mr. Abner H. Gregory was so len in Z d in tbe presence of a large audeuce. The church was decorated with cedar, chrysanthemums and carna tions and lighted with hundreds of candles. The bride met the groom under a large bell of flowers where her minister, Rev. George S. Ken- naid performed the ceremony in a very impressive manner. Miss Margaret Smith, teacher of music at the Union Acade uy oi Spout Springs, had jchaige of the music and played softly several se lections while the service was being performed. Mr. E. H. Matthew- 6on, who is at the headof the U. S. Experimental Station here, sang very sweetly Loves Old Sweet Song. Mrs. Frank Sheard, of Lynch burg, was matron of honor, and wore pink dress with roses. Miss Maude Gregory, sister of the gr-.om was maid of honor, and wore white net over pink silk and carried white roses. Capt. Nathan C. Hancock, broth er of the bride was best man. The brides attendants were Miss Margurite Marshall with Harry Hancock Miss Emma Smith with Walter B. Ellett Miss Helen Gregory with H. W. McKinney Miss Bertha Caldwell with A. .V. The bride wore white net trimmed in real lace over whine taffeta, and Uer bridal veil was caught with a beautiful brooch set with  tails, a gift from tbe groom, and a diamond pin, an heirloom of the family. She carried in her hand a white ptajer- book. They boarded the wes bound train tor a tiip west and will be at home to their tneuds here after the ,2tn. The bride is the very attractive young daughter of Mr. C. W. Han cock, a popular contractor of Lynchburg aud this place, and is one of the prominent and Highly connected families of the .Kate. The gioom is a fine young man of sterling qualities, a son ot Mr. N. H. Giegory, of this place arid holds a position with the N.  W. Ry. Co where be is highly esteemed by his comrades and employers. The presents presented to tbe bride were of a very high order, among them a deed to tbe hand somer. t home in the county from the father of tbe bride. This home has just been completed here and e healed throughout with generators, lighted,by acetylene gas -iud con tains every modern convenience. Tbe presents number 125 all told, and the bride is extremely happy and appreciative ovarihe thought fulness of her frieuds. RECEPTION. document.text: T he D ea th o f M rs. M cK inney. Seldom has a death of a member of our community affected everyone so sadly as that of Mrs. Lelia McKin ney, wife of Mr. Frank W. McKin ney. The announcement of her death and its suddenness sent a shock through the entire community. On Monday last she was taken very ill at about 11 oclock at night, and the conditions being very alarming,riders were sent out in all directions for physicians. Drs. W. H. Abbitt and A. A. Rice were found and promptly responded to the summons. They did all that was possible to alleviate her sufferings and to tide her over the dangerous illness, but when the evening shades of Tuesday began to fall, Mrs McKinney passed away. The hour of her death was 5 oclock Many of her friends were telegraphed for from Lynchburg and Richmond and among those who came by the earliest train were Mr. and Mrs. Wal ter McKinney,Mrs. Poore, of Lynch burg, and Mr. Charles Peers, of Rich mond. The funeral services, which oc curred yesterday at 4 oclock, were conducted by Rev. E. M. Craig, as sisted by Rev. W. S. Royall. The re mains of the deceased were interred in the old family cemetery, just the rear of the house. A very large number of friends and relatives were present to witness the last sad rites. Mrs. McKinney was a native of Appomattox, having passed her life, until a few months ago, at OldAp- pomattox Court-House. She was a daughter of Mr. Geb. Peers, our pre sent county clerk. She was married only last May, and at the time of her death was thirty-three years of age. She was a member of the Presby terian church, and her character as a Christian and as a womanwas sfffih that it would be almost an intrusion to touch upon it. As her pastor, Mr. Craig, said, she never let a day pass without showing by some kindly j act the impress of Christs spirit ppon her.

document.text: R esolutions o f R espect. The following paper was read and adopted by the business men of Glade Spring Whereas, It has pleased an all wise Providence tp remove our as sociate, C. W. McKinney, from , our midst, therefore. Resolved, That we have sustained the loss of a man whose character endeared him to each of us as a per sonal friend. That, In energy, liberality, frank ness, courtesy aud kindness, he set us an example well worthy of emu lation. That, Knowing him as we did, from earliest manhood, it is a pleas ure to testify to the uniform consis tency of his life. His business meth ods were snch as to make friends of those with whom he had dealings, while they brought success as their result. That, As a citizen and man, his duty was faithfully done. That, In his death We are bereaved, and join our lament with that of his stricken family. That, Our sympathy deep and heartfelt, is tendered to the wife and children who suffer an irreparable loss in the .death of husband and father. That, A copy of these resolutions be furnished to the Glade Spring Citizen for publication. J. D. K en t ,  J. D. W il lia m s , V Com. M. M. M oruis 8 . j Feb. 8 th, 1894. Mr. C. W. McKinney, in reference to whom the above resolutions were adopted, was at one time a resident of Appomattox. He was a brother of Messrs. Walton and F, W. McKin ney.Editor

document.text: Misses Hancock E n tertain On Monday evening Misses Virginia and Margaret Han cock gave a most elaborate fancy dress party at their home here. Mr. and Mrs. C. A. Hancack, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hancock, Mrs. W. B. Caldwell, Mrs. C. F James, Mrs George Purdnm and Mrs. Frank McKinney were in the receiving line with the young ladies. The guests enjoyed the various games in troduced. The most enjoyable being the 30 grains of corn valu ed at 1 each which was the currency used to buy the many mementoes of the occaseion, which were purchased by the Misses Hancock while touring Europe this summer, and which were offered at auction by auctioneer Howlett Martin. The Miller Ochestra, of Lynch burg, furnished the music. The guests were ushered into the dinning room elaborately decorated with golden rod, where supper wae served for the great party. The evening came to a close with every heart full of appre ciation to the Misses Hancock for the most enjoyable party of its kind ever given in onr little town.

document.text: Miss Maryland Virginia Smith,37, secretary to the superin,endent at the State Penitentiary, was killed instantly shortly after 7 oclock Sunday night when siie was s ruck by an automobile as she walked along route 460 about half a mile east of Bedford. Driver of the automobile, Russell W. Orange, 19, of Thaxton, was booked on a charge of manslaughter and released on 2,000 bond at Bedford county jail. Miss Smith was walking along the highway wiih . er sister, Mrs. R. W. Jamerson, of Webber City, just outside Bed ford, when she was hit. She was spending the week-end with her sis- .. According to deputy sheriff Dillard W. Shields, the two women were walking eastward along the side- of the highway when the Orange machine, traveling in the same direction, passed another ma chine, operated by Roy Bowyer, of Bocock Crossing, and struck Miss Smith as the two cars were running adjacent along the road. Besides Mrs. Jamerson, Miss mAh is survived by her father, M. C. Smith of Appomattox an other sister, Mrs. O. L. Sihefflerof Appomattox and six brothers, C. W. Abbitt, who has been sick in a Norfolk hospital, has been brought to her home here. Mrs. A. R. Harwood has re turned from a ten days visit to her sister, Mrs. Taylor, of Stapleton. document.text: MEMORIAL EXERCISES, FRIDAY JUNE 1 -4 OCLOCK P. fl. The procession will file out from the lot adjoining N. U. Gregorys. Line of march will be as follow! Up Grove avenue to Main, out Main to Court, then along the quiet high way to the cemetery. Leadiug the procession will be the Confederate veterans, followed by the aides of the chief marshal. Chief-marshalMaj. J. W. Flood. MarshalsMessrs. Ned LeGrand, R. F. Burke, Johu T. Lee, John W. White, Jas. P. L. Fleshman, G. L. Ferguson, Daniel Ferguson, N. H. Gregory, Geo. T. Peers, W. H. Ab bitt. AidesMessrs. J. G. Fisher, J. W. Trent, C. A. Trent, F. W. McKin ney, John Overton, R. C. Harvey, H. W. McKinney, Joe OBrien, Wat kins Nowlin, Hunter Abbitt, Robt. Caldwell, Walter Ellett, Frank Ab bitt, Hnbbard Coleman, Joel Cole man, Ran. Fleshman, R. C. Mann, George Purdum, R. L. Burke, J. W. Childsess, Jake Childress, and J. B. Abbitt, Daniel Browning. Next in line will be the Daugh ters of the Confederacy and ladies of the Memorial Association, follow ed by young ladies as flower-bearers then citizens and friends. The solemn exercises at the cem etery will be opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Taylor, followed by singing Nearer, my God, to Thee, recita tion by Miss Mary L. Paris, intro ductory remarks by Hou. Henry D. Flood, address b y ---------- , singing, recitation by Miss Alice Burke. The flag bearers will be Misses Lucy Smith and Pearl Burke. The exercises will be closed with prayer by Rev. P. M. Bell. All Confederate veterans are cor dially invited to take part in these exeeises.

document.text: Having Been In the commission and grocery business forjthe past two years and, we are glad to say, have succeeded far beyond our expectations, and we thank our friends and the public generally, for the liberal support which we can assure them is highly appreciated by us. See ing this to bo almost a necessity and for reaching in its good effeet.not only to usbut our trade, wo have added In an adjoining room dry goods, notions, boots, shoes ,hats and ready made clothing to our stock which gives us an almost complete stoekof everything that is sold, en abling us to sell close to our customers and also to sell them everything they want, so when you come you will tind everything you need at Morris Uros.  Co.- Wo wish to say in regard to our dry goods department that it is entirely complete, our Mr. Geo H Morris, who has ehargeof tins department, having been in this business for 22 years has given his especial attention to it and we can safely say we cannot be undersold. In our dress goods we have silks from 25c. to 1.25 per yard and all the latest shades and styles of other dross fabrics, ladies and gents shoes and slippers of every description and kind and at figures that cannot be duplicated anywhere. document.text: Featured by a ringing en dorsement of former governor iarry Flood Byrd for the Dem- ocatic presidential nomination, and the mention of Senator lamuel L. Ferguson as an ideal candidate for the governorship of Virginia, Democrats of Ap pomattox county met here yes terday afternoon in annual mass meeting. Called to order by chairman Don Moses, the Democrats lost io time in getting down to bus- ness. Mr. Moses and C. W. hnith, secretary, were made lermanent officers. C. W. Imith introduced  motion as égards methods of selection of ounty delegates to thé state ionvention and a committee was named to present a list of nominations. -- Senator Ferguson was recog nized and read a resolution en dorsing Byrd for the presiden- - cy. The resolution was unani- , . mously adopted. Resolutions . were then presented commend ing the administration of Gov- arnor Pollard, the record of Senator Ferguson, of delegate A. J .Terrell, of the United States senators and represen- tlves of Virginia, and of the ounty officials of Appomattox. J. A. Burke added an aitiend-  ment to the resolution lauding. Senator Ferguson, to commend lim to the Democrats of Vir ginia as the ideal candidate for the governorship. Applause greeted this amendment and it was adopted by a standing vote, f. Ç. Cawthorn, Jr., added an amendment to t h e resolution ommending the county officers o include the splendid service of Judge Robert Hutchinson. The delegation to the state convention will consist of forty- sight, with one-fourth of a vote sach. They will vote as a unit. R. L. Burke was named chair man of the delegation, with Don Moses as assistant. The state convention meets June 9, in the Mosque, Richmond. The list of delegates follows S. L. Ferguson, J. W. Flood, R. L. document.text: Dear Lord we give him up to Thee Tho sorrowing from the heart. Content If Thou w ilt let us m eet Some day to never part. _____________ . ________ M ary . Notes from O akville. E ditor T iem s Our visit to the Court House on Thursday last was a pleasure long to be remembered, and the inclinatioti to express it through the medium of your paper, is irresist ible. I was a little relnctant to make the trip on court day, but the opportunity was such a good one, withnotanotherinhailingdistance, I found myself unable to trust to luck, and ventured a drive through streets filled with creations lords. The youth and beauty, however, of my friend and companion arrested the gaze of all observers, and I was, for tunately, left to blnsh unseen. The first to greet me on our ar rival at Hotel Appomattox was Rev. Mr. Craig, who iB to succeed our be loved pastor at Union. His beaming face and preposessing manners are living credentials of an  all-sufficient substitute, and I am satisfied that the little flock at Union will be more reconciled to the ex change, when they know him. We wire most cordially received, and nicely entertained by Mr. and Mrs. Smith, whose charming daughters added much to the enjoy ment of onr visit The table was bountifully spread with a variety of the most palatable food. Indeed I never enjoyed abetter meal. I met up with several old friends, and formed some pleasant acquaint ances, among whom were Mrs. Peers, Mr. Charlie Saekett, Dr. Kearney, Mr. and Mrs. Frank McKinney, and Dr. John Hamlet. Our visit to the T imes office was very much enjoyed. The press was quite a curiosity to us both, aud the thought of having seen the source from whence flows so much good sense, wit and humor is gratifying. Many thanks for your kindness in showing us around. Long may the gloom-dispelling T imes continue to brighten the homes of its readers. Sept. 12,1893. L one star .

document.text: Governor Names Road Delegates. Thirty official delegates from Vir ginia to the American Road Congress, scheduled to be held In Detroit, Mich., September 29 to October 4, were named by Governor Mann, and com missions issued from the office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth to each of the delegates. Governor Mann also sent a letter to L. W. Page, presi dent of the American Road Congress, in Washington, notifying him of the appointment of the delegation and in closing a list of the members. The American Road Congress is one of the largest and most powerful or ganizations working in the United States in the interest of good roads, and has accomplished a great work in th awakening of the country to the advantages to be derived from well- built highways. The meeting of the congress in Detroit is expected to be of unusual interest. The list of delegates appointed by Governor Mann follows First DistrictAshton Fletcher, Jen kins Bridge Thomas B. document.text: The Storm. A terrible storm passed over West Appomattox and vicinity last Thurs day evening doing considerable dam age to property aud growing crops. Ihe hail stones were the largest ever seen hereas large as guinea eggs. Every exposed window in the vil was broken and many rooms were flooded. The rainfall was very heavy and the streams of the county held people returning fr,m court water bound. Lightning struck the livery stable of Mr.  inston McKinney and killed two fine horses, one belonging to Mr. Frank Jeuniugs, of Lyuchburg, and the other to Mr. McKinuev, and damaging the stable considerably. Tbe rain was general but the hail seems to have been confined to a narrow territory of about five miles, sqareWst Appomattox being the cen ter. During the storm Hon. W. H. Ligon was sitting in the furniture establishment of Mr. T. A. Smith near a window reading, when a pane of glass was broken by the hail and flying piece of the glass struck him sqarely m the right eye, fearfully larcerating the pupil. Urs. Robert son and Abbitt examined the wound and both think he will loose the sight of his eye entirely. A letter received from Mr. Ligon yesterday stated that he was suffering very much and that both eyes appeared to be effected by the accident. Mr. Ligons friends are very solicitous abovt him and trust his sight will not he permanently effected.

document.text: ST. ANNS EPISCOPAL CHURCH Sunday, April 12 945 A. M., Church School. 1100 A. M. Morning Prayer Rev. Robert E. Withers. WILSON - WOOTTON Bakersville, N. C.- A ceremony of beauty and simplicity uniting in mar riage Miss Viola Christine Wootton, of Lenoir, N. C., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. W. Wootton of Appo mattox, Va., and Kenneth Guy Wil son, also of Lenoir, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Wilson, of Bakersville, N. C., was performed on Thursday morning March 19, at 1100 oclock at the McKinney Cove Baptist Church in Bakersville with the Rev. Ernest S. Canipp officiating, using the double ring ceremony. The bride and groom entered the room together, unattended. The bride wore a powder blue suit with white and navy accessories, and carried a white Bible topped with a purple throated white orchid. The bride is a graduate of E. C.., Glass High School in Lynchburg, Va., receiving her commercial train ing also in Lynchburg, She is now employed in the office of the Bern hardt Furniture Co. in Lenoir, N. C. The bridegroom is a graduate of Bakersville, N. C. school, after which he served 3 years in the U. S. Army,

document.text: P A K M V IL L K . Farmviile is still bjMy clearing away the wreckagejgft in the wake of the stormyThe blockaded streets hasrfieen opened np and the injured residences will pressed. The Iocs in every in stance total, as no one thought of tornado insurance. The one e x e r tion being in the case of Mcttrs. Richardson and Cralle who carried plate glass insurance. One of their front windows was destoyed bv a falling tree and for this they will be fully paid. The fire alarm w.is again soui.ded on a recent evening and the blaze soon located in th  residence o B. J. Harvey, of South Main street. The flatnes were soon under control, but not before the house and furni ture were seriously damaged. Lou, however, fully covered by insurance as is generally true when fires occur in towns or cities. Let the owners of country property think of these things. Sales of tobacco have been heavy of late in this market, but the farm ers are still kicking against prices And no wonder that they should Hard work to grow the weed and harder still to sell it below the profit mak. The recent heavy rains wrought great damage to the low lands of the ebunty. It is fe tred that some of the acres are beyond the working in the future. This means serious loss. A larger crop of lettuce was plant ed in the fall than had been done for previous seasons, but the exces sive cold of winter killed ont many of the plants. Those living, how ever, are growing off nicely. News of the death of Mr. J. R. Atwood caused genuine sorrow among his many Farmviile friends, who knew him only to honor him. The writer had often enjoyed the generous and gracious hospitality of his palatial home and will cherish his memory. For the stricken household he extends heartfelt sym- part by. At the last meeting of the Board of Supervisors for Prince Edward one concrete bridge was ordered and others may follow. It is abont time that public officials were learn ing that whats worth doing at all is worth doing well. Bridges should bd built not for a day but for all time so far as man can build for all time. The grass is spreading over our fields and lawns and now and then some premature bud is peeping from winter quarters. .Mrs. R. Baxter Tuggle recently celebrated the 21st anniversary of her wedding day by having a largi number of her lady friends to meet - her at a reception in the home of her mother, Mrs. Berkeley. The old home was artistically and hand  somely decorated for the occasion,  the yellow of early spring being the  reigning color, dainty refreshments  were served and the evening bright and memorable in the social history  of Farmviile. The reception only lasted from five to 733 p. m., bu during the time scores of friends were received and served. Mr. Frank Epps recently bought a horse on the Richmond market  with a trotting record of 216, and had the misfortune to lose the ani- . maj soon after reaching hi i stable. Death was caused by something like  pneumonia contacted on the train from Richmond. It is said that Mine host, Chick, P will no longer run the Randolph p hotel after the expiration of his lease 3 in August, and a hotel man from p Lancaster, Ohio, has been here  looking over the situation. It must be a fine, opening for some first- i class hotel man. i Our milliners have had their jggpingsand now the girls know jnst how the Easter bonnets look while the boys are waiting anxious judgment upon them af ten they adorn beautys brow. pr. and Mrs. Rouss, of Coving ton, Ky., have been guests of Mrs. Annie McKinney. Mrs. Lucy Dunuington Shields, df Lexington, Va., is visiting in the old home. Mrs, Florida Fitzgerald improves steadily... Mrs. Mai ia Thornton has return- pifto Chari ston, W. Va., whereshi trill finish her visit to friends, hav- idjj been called home on account of the illness of Mrs. Fitzgerald. The news that Senator Swanson bad gotten the unanimous consent of the Senate for a 6,000 appro priation for a Government building for Farmviile gave genuine satin- faction to all our people. We will no doubt squabble over a site, cat

document.text: My friend, Mr. D. W. Gill, of this place, gave me hi copy of your paper of the 21st of September and also of the 5th of this month which contained the roil anti supplement of Co. K, 4th Va. Cavalry, and if we are not depredating too much on time and space in yonr valuable paper would be glad if yon would add s few more names to that already long list, which I can call to memory. Baldwin A., Baldwin, Bob, Kikin Cleaveland, Thornton Frank, Cox George, Hazlegrove Tomas, Hazle- grove Cbas., Hazlegrove Henry, Powell Jake, Steger M.D. and Lack- land George. Both papers gave the same Stegerone James and the other 8ydnorwhich was the same man as his name was J. S. Steger. I have forgotten M. D.s initials in fall, in fact I cannot give none of the names in fail, bat I can give vou Lieut. Gills, his v.as Robt. H., ind was our 1st Lieutenant elect at the New Store, and was killed in tbe V lley of Virginia while gallantry leading a charge. Lieut. Wm. A. Vf 088 was then made 1st Lieutenant ind commanded Co. K the balance f the war faithfully and fearlessly. Lieutenant Nat Morris was elected 2d Lisritenant, but was put in com mand of the stnd horse battalion un .il that command was annihilated tnd then he was promoted to com mander in chief of Co. Q. Lieut. G. C. Croxton was onr best lieuten ant and he was appointed by Col. fftokham and killed at Five Forks, Dinwiddie county, Va. H. S. Crute -vos onr 1st o rderly sergeant, B. H. Carter was onr quartermaster ser geant. Capt. McKinney wae wound ed at Stcvensburg in his knee and disabled for the balance of the war. t would give yon the dates if I could, lint I have forgotten them. In nam ing George Lackland brings to my mind a little incident that occared -it Spotsylvania C. H. during our big fight there. We had been fighting three or four days with infantry un til Gen. Stnart relieved ns with Gen. facksons men and we went into camp on Saturday night. Bnt about wo hoars before day on Sunday morning were ordered to prepare two or three days rations, and by light we started and was marched ip to the Court House and the Hrick Church tbe Fourth Regiment vas dismounted and ordered iu sup port of the Sixth Virginia Cavalry which was fast being driven in our direction, and we had hardly started when some of the boys said Charge, and just here Maj. Wool- ridge, who was in command of tbe Fourth Virginia Regiment, lost hie leg. We ran these skirmishers back icross a branch and up a hill some five h indred yards, and just on top - f this hill a new rail fence ten rails and stake and rider. Right here we ooys haled and commenced looking for something to get behind for ight in front of us and in plain view was a double line of yanxee in- antry. Well, sir, they soon open ed on us and I tell you the splinters tlew. But we were not there long before a ball struck Sergeant John S. Nickolas on the counter cf his boot when he cried out, Lord haveTner ey on me! D------that trick toh Barbee take nié out, and we jump d up and started. I had thought up to this time that I was pretty id on a race, but John gained on me at at every jump. And in run ning down that hill there was a washout in which we found George Lackland and he asked us to please take him out and we assisted him to get out and we started again and he after us. The Third Regiment had been dismounted and marched to this branch in support of the Fourth and when I got there they told me t bat the boys had passed sometime, and I waited uutil our regiment was ordered in and then we started from there in pursuit of Sheridan, who was marchiDg on to Ri- hniond. do not suppose that m old friends could put up such a run now. Mr. Editor, when you think all the names from different sources have been obtained, please print the whole list giving every man his proper distinction, and then the ros ter will be in the proper shape for Mr. Ellis to put in the clerks office, and in the pioper shape for each member of old Co, K to keep also, and pleise send me a copy, which kindness I will greatly appreciate. My best love to all the boys. I would be delighted to see them. Respectfully, A. A. B a r b e e .

document.text: Mr. H. M. Crowder was in town last week. Mrs. Lavona Crowder made short visit to Mrs. S. L. Fer guson last week. Miss Alice Proffitt left last week for Cleveland, Ohio, where she will live for a while A d a m e Bros.-Paynes Co., Lynchburg, have change of ad ou this page. Sheriff McKinney wants a jailer, but there is no one in jail. Mrs. R. N. Dawson, of Rich mond, is visiting her parents, Mr. and Mrs. R. H. Browning, near here. Mr. George Paris gave a few of his friends a party Saturday night, the 20 th, which was his birthday. Mr. and Mrs. 0. G. Chandler have returned home, after a very pleasant visit spent with home people near Burkeville. Miss Kyle Davis, of Culpep- , Va., has been on a visit to cousin, Miss Eula May Burke, for several days. WantedColored family oa large farm. Good wages and land for orking people. Address, with prticnlars, Box 28, Route 1 , Ever green, Va. 110 3w Mr. Moses Hunter has nine children down with measles. he children are doing well, and Mose is a very busy man. Mr. C S. Frank was a visitor in Appomattox today. He has recently bought a farm in the Southside of the county. A large attendance of far mers is earnestly desired here at the C. H. Saturday, to or ganize a Farm Loan Bank. Are you coming? W hats the N. Sc W. going to do for the people of Appomat tox, since the people yielded to iheir contention for the dos lag of the main street crossing? Mr. Jessie Harvey sold on tbe Appomattox tobocco mar ket to-day 1000 lbs, for which he received 224.86. What market can beat it? If you want the farms of Ap pomattox to keep up with the progress of the State, come out Saturday and help organise the  federal Farm Laud Bank. Are you ooming? Supervisor L. E. Smih at tended the recent good roads meeting in Norfolk. Len is a ive supervisor, and wants Ap ppmattox to stand for progress, good roads. FARMERS! .Tobacco is selling high. You ought to start your plant beds for this years crop right, by 6  ng Old Dominion Guano on it. have jnat received a carload of eah m tde goods. 17 2 w E. L e R oy S mith . Rev. McElroy has been con fined to his home since Monday with a deep cold. He is much better and expects to be ready for the prayer meeting Thurs day night. Miss Pocahontas Wray, of Martinsville, Va., is on a visit to the Dormitory here. Miss Wray was teacher here for our years, and her friends are glad to have her with them Evergreen Baptist church Quarterly church meeting Sat urday, 27tb, at 230 p. m Preaching Sunday morning 11 oclock, and 8 unday afternoon oclock. My boy left home about tbe last of. February a year ago His name is Levi. Any infor mation about his present resi ilence will be highly appreciat ed. Has large eyes, 15 years of age, black. J a s . W . F lood , Appomattox, Va, There will be a meeting of tbe Appomattox Barred Rock Associa non on Feb. 2nd at 230 p. m. All members are urged to toe present, ae Mr. N. E. B. Talcott, State Ponltry Agent, will be he, e and will give ,ou some interesting information, 1 24 2w E. LeRoy Smith, Sec Preaching at Memorial Meth odist church Sunday at 11 a.m by the Presiding Elder of the Lynchburg district. Rev. W .T Green, who will preach again Monday morning at 11 a. m and hold the first quarterly conference of the year. Ser vices Sunday evening at 730 by the pastor. Subject, T te Power of the Gross. Sundagr school at 10 a. m. and proytv meeting Wednesday evening at 730. Everybody invited to attend these servioee.

document.text: F A R M V I L L E . Some of the houses in this towi have been so crowded with visitor dining the summer that the house keepers are enjoying the though that the emptying process will sooi begin. Evidently Farmville it growing in favor as a summer re sort and with its location, lithii water and other advantages it de- strves to attract widespread atten tion. The more I know of othe sections of the State the more am  satisfied that the Southside is th home of physical comfort. O il tables are much better supplied our nights are never uncomiortab ly warm, we havent the mosquito, the water is soft and good even where and as far as our people, well we will let others sing theii praises. The melon fadure has produced contusion in the ranks of tin brothers in black. The happiest human being I ever saw was old Goliah, many years dead, with a water melon all his own. How we do miss the peaches. Can we not introduce the use of the canvass for the peach orchard as well as the tobacco beds? We used to find them in the fence cor ners and along the roadside, and and they were good. Whats wrong with nature? Or is the fault with man? That drinking fountain f r Main Street is yet non est, but the dis pensary is  doing bittiness at the old stand. Editor Hart carries his head somewhat higher since Supervisors honors rest on him. He hasnt an nounced, however, that he would stand lor the legislature next time The Presbyterians have been greatly pleased with the preaching of Rev. Mr. Hatcher, pastor of the Methodist church, during the month of August and while their pastor was on his vacation. I suppose before the gates close a large majority of the people of Farmville will have been to the Ex position. Mrs. Miller, of Pennsylvania, is a guest at Mrs. Berkleys. Mrs. Dr. Crute has been visiting friends in Charlotte. Miss Frank Jones, who has been with friends is Smithfield is at home ai Hampden Sidney again. At the recent meeting of the Jewelers of the State Mayor Blanton was made 1st Vice-president of the body. He is an accomplished occu- list as well as expert jeweler. The Hampden Sidney boys and the Normalites will soon be report ing for duty. This means another year gone, and to some of us that means much. Miss Stone, who has been writ ing to the Roanoke Times from here, has been saying some hand some things of Farmville. Captain Hunt has been so impor tuned not to resign from the com inand of the guards that the hope is entertained that he will not do BO. The new conservatory of music is opened for scholars. Prof. G. W. Walker, of Blacks burg, will make the opening- ad dress at Hampden Sidney this year. No pastor has yet been selected for College church. Farmville will be crowded with amusements for the coming season. But the new railroads are slow- a-coming. It must be interesting to some people just to project new enterprises and leave them in the air after the  hot air has been ex pended. The old-time farmers picnic was a great success. Tobacco still demands first claims on our cash and is sure to get it. A winsome weed is she. The Methodists are hoping to dedicate their new church building in the near future and when that is done they will have oue of the most attractive ho ises of worship in the Common weal lb and with the Nor mal contingent the congregation will be one of the most interesting. Rev. Mr. Hatcher preached a noble sermon on last Sunday, his text being,  Keep thy heart for out of it are the issues of life. Judge Laudon C. Flourney, of Kentucky, has been a visitor in the borne of Mrs. J. R. Fitzgerald, his P sister. His father, the late W. C. Flourney, was a lawyer of com manding ability. Misses Pattie and Maggie Wnj kins, daughters of the late Judi F. W. Watkins, are visiting friend in Farmville and furroundinji to an try. Air. C. D. McKinney, a son jfce late S. B. McKinney and botfl rninent attorney at the Aidant

document.text: Domestic. Judgi Waddill, in the United States CouTt in Richmond, Va., decided that by applying for a receiver the Trigg Shipbuilding Company did not commit an act of bankruptcy.  James McKinney, the last of the out laws who broke out of prison at Glas gow, Mont., was shot to death by a fanner, in whose icehouse he had taken refuge. Frank C. Jappe, cashier and book keeper for the Frank Leslie Publish ing Company in New York, was ar rested, charged with robbing the com pany of about 10,000. George Bartuski, who claimed to be a violin virtuoso, was arrested in Eliz abeth, N. J., on the charge of being a counterfeiter. Vice President Loomis, of the Dela ware and Lackawanna, declared there would be enough hard coal to supply all demands this year. Lightning strnck a hut stored with 3000 pounds of dynamite rear Seneca- ville, O. Six men were killed in the explosion and a score injured. Maurice OHearn, a night watchman, was shot and killed by a suspicious- looking tnan whom he had challenged. The court in Pittsburg allowed Dr. W. C. Browning 54,163.18 against the estate of the late C. L. Magee. The State Bank of Oakley, Kan. was robbed and 3000.
